title: 111_s1803
content: The Act titled "Federal Reserve Accountability Act of 2009" requires reviews of special Federal Reserve credit facilities. The "Federal Reserve Accountability Act of 2009" mandates reviews of specific credit facilities of the Federal Reserve System, including various programs like the Money Market Investor Funding Facility and the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility. The "Federal Reserve Accountability Act of 2009" authorizes the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal Reserve bank, including auditing, financial reporting, and internal controls. The "Federal Reserve Accountability Act of 2009" authorizes the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board or any Federal Reserve bank. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. The Comptroller General is prohibited from disclosing specific participant names or identifying details of audited facilities, assets, or collateral. This nondisclosure obligation expires after a certain period, after which the Comptroller General must release a redacted report. The Comptroller General must release a nonredacted version of reports on credit facilities one year after their termination. Access to records is expanded to include specific partnerships, corporations, and agency facilities. The Comptroller General is allowed to make and keep copies of records. The Comptroller General can access and make copies of records from specific partnerships, corporations, and agency facilities as needed for review or examination. SEC. 3. PUBLIC ACCESS TO INFORMATION. The Board is required to provide public access to various reports and financial statements on its website for a minimum of 6 months. This includes reports by the Comptroller General, annual financial statements by an independent auditor for the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and other relevant information for public understanding of accounting and financial controls. The Board and the Federal Reserve banks oversee accounting, financial reporting, and internal controls.
